text: Is JLD2 safe even though it is not actively maintained anymore?

elements.text: Is JLD2 safe even though it is not actively maintained anymore?

text: > *NOTE*: This package is now *actively maintained again*!

elements.text: NOTE
: This package is now
actively maintained again

text: it's being maintained again :smile:. I've been using it for some simple things and it's been working great. Haven't tried anything very complicated though.

elements.text: it's being maintained again
. I've been using it for some simple things and it's been working great. Haven't tried anything very complicated though.

text: I’ve been using it for a lot data saving for RL experiments. I don’t have many issues, but am hoping we get some better compression support soon.

elements.text: I’ve been using it for a lot data saving for RL experiments. I don’t have many issues, but am hoping we get some better compression support soon.

text: You might also want to checkout BSON, as it is quite good too.

elements.text: You might also want to checkout BSON, as it is quite good too.
And FileIO.jl

text: my colleague <@US8SVNCCU> ran into a pretty crazy issue with BSON: <https://github.com/JuliaIO/BSON.jl/issues/75>. I'd be wary myself.

elements.text: my colleague
ran into a pretty crazy issue with BSON:
. I'd be wary myself.

text: Yaaaaaay!  How can I install it?  Please explain like I’m grandma.

elements.text: Yaaaaaay!  How can I install it?  Please explain like I’m grandma.

text:
press `]` in your REPL to go into package mode.
Add it via `add JLD2`
now you can exit pkg mode by pressing backspace 2x
then type `using JLD2` to import it into your REPL/project

elements.text: press

in your REPL to go into package mode.
Add it via
add JLD2

now you can exit pkg mode by pressing backspace 2x
then type
using JLD2
to import it into your REPL/project

text:
I've used JLD2 for some pretty weird stuff with little issue - but yea it isn't unlimited. For basic stuff though, IE you want to serialize some arrays or something it's easy.

One thing to keep in mind is, if you upgrade your Julia version, your JLD2 files are likely no longer openable(in the new version). At least that used to be the case.

elements.text:
I've used JLD2 for some pretty weird stuff with little issue - but yea it isn't unlimited. For basic stuff though, IE you want to serialize some arrays or something it's easy.

One thing to keep in mind is, if you upgrade your Julia version, your JLD2 files are likely no longer openable(in the new version). At least that used to be the case.

text: but if you're careful you can literally serialize julia functions and stuff, it's pretty crazy... At least I think that was via JLD2...

elements.text: but if you're careful you can literally serialize julia functions and stuff, it's pretty crazy... At least I think that was via JLD2...

text: At this point, what is the advantage of JLD2 over JLD?  The docs seem to imply the latter (JLD) is still “safer”, and it’s worked fine for my elementary usage in recent days

elements.text: At this point, what is the advantage of JLD2 over JLD?  The docs seem to imply the latter (JLD) is still “safer”, and it’s worked fine for my elementary usage in recent days

text: For serializing Flux models, JLD just failed with very unhelpful errors, while JLD2 just worked. Also JLD2 is now maintained, and seems more active and likely to have traction than JLD going forward.

elements.text: For serializing Flux models, JLD just failed with very unhelpful errors, while JLD2 just worked. Also JLD2 is now maintained, and seems more active and likely to have traction than JLD going forward.
